summary: ‘I’m … nobody!’ He scratched his head. 'I have forgotten who I am!’ said Odysseus. The girl took Odysseus by the hand and said,...
text: ‘I’m … nobody!’ He scratched his head. 'I have forgotten who I am!’ said Odysseus. The girl took Odysseus by the hand and said, 'Well, come with me…
source: The If Odyssey: A Philosophical Journey Through Greek Myth and Storytelling for 8 - 16-Year-Olds; Peter Worley

summary: The events are not out of order. He originally meant to go to The Eyrie but wasn't able to because of the Mountain Clans, then...
question: The events are not out of order. He originally meant to go to The Eyrie but wasn't able to because of the Mountain Clans, then he decided to head to Riverrun. Then he heard the news about the PW and Sansa/Tyrion etc. Then he heard the news about Riverrun under siege, then he got a mortal wound. However, after he got the wound he told Arya they will take a ship to The Vale instead of going through the Mountains, and during the journey to Saltpans he collapsed because of the wounds.
answer:
Sorry, need more coffee apparently.  Okay, so after the wound he does suggest taking a ship from the Saltpans to the Vale yes.  

“Saltpans.” He put a big hand on her shoulder to keep from falling. “Get some wine, she-wolf. And take whatever coin they have as well, we’ll need it. If there’s ships at Saltpans, we can reach the Vale by sea.” His mouth twitched at her, as more blood ran down from where his ear had been. “Maybe Lady Lysa will marry you to her little Robert. There’s a match I’d like to see.” He started to laugh, then groaned instead.   

That mouth twitch means he’s thinking more than he is saying, but I don’t think this is about Sansa directly.  Obviously, she’s always on his mind, but he has no idea where she would have gone into hiding or how she got out of KL.  He makes a joke of Lysa marrying Arya to Robert.  If he thought Sansa might be there, I don’t think this joke would occur to him as the older sister has the inheritance claim for Lysa to want such a marriage.  There’s the more pressing matter of Arya at hand.  He has come to legitimately care about Arya (relating to her trauma and anger), which is why he hasn’t cut is losses and abandoned her.  I think the twitch means he knows he is bleeding out pretty badly and there is a possibility he may not recover.  He’s seen enough wounds like this in his life, even recently with the dying archer.  So he’s probably telling Arya the plan so that she’ll know how to go on without him just in case.  To him Lysa is still her safest bet if Arya can get to her.  He’s still going to try to make it for both their sakes, but then it becomes apparent when they reach the Trident he’s getting weaker.

When he got the fire going, Sandor propped up his helm in the flames, emptied half the wineskin into it, and collapsed back against a jut of moss-covered stone as if he never meant to rise again. He made Arya wash out the squire’s cloak and cut it into strips. Those went into his helm as well. “If I had more wine, I’d drink till I was dead to the world. Maybe I ought to send you back to that bloody inn for another skin or three." 

"No,” Arya said. He wouldn’t, would he? If he does, I’ll just leave him and ride off.

Sandor laughed at the fear on her face. “A jest, wolf girl. A bloody jest.”

Yeah, he’s starting to come to terms with the fact that these wounds are serious and this isn’t looking good.  He claims this is a jest, but there’s truth there.  With his guilt for botching up the first rescue attempt, his learning that he left her to a fate worse than death (in his opinion), I think he feels nothing but despair over Sansa.  He blames himself for everything that befell her, even if she got away.  So he probably thinks she blames him too for his screw-ups and would never want to see him again.  The least he can do for her now is to try to save her sister.  Without Arya to look out for, I think he would just give up, find some wine, and just drink himself to death.  But he decides to use the last of their wine to treat his wounds.  I don’t think it can be overstated that Sandor is facing his deepest fear of being burned by having Arya pour the boiling wine into his wounds.  He saw Arya’s fear of being alone on her face (no matter that she thinks she would abandon him) and decided to keep going for as long as he can.

body:
Jaqen H'ghar : You kissed me and the two I was with.
Arya Stark : I didn't kiss you !

Arya Stark : Seven hells ! I like you.
Jaqen H'ghar : It is known.

summary: Do you think that after Sandor heard that Sansa fled KL, he decided to go to the Eyrie partially because he thought Sansa...
question: Do you think that after Sandor heard that Sansa fled KL, he decided to go to the Eyrie partially because he thought Sansa might've fled to there?
answer:
Those events are out of order.  It was post-Red Wedding in Arya XII, ASOS that Sandor tries to take Arya to her aunt, where she would presumably be safe away from the fighting.  Up until that point, his (wildly unrealistic) plan was to use Arya as leverage to join Robb’s army, get himself a lordship, and rescue Sansa when Robb presumably sacks KL.  When that plan is dashed, the next best thing is to get Arya to the Eyrie to perhaps collect a ransom. That gets thwarted when they learn the road up to the Bloody Gate is snowed in and there have been more aggressive Mountain Clan attacks.  It’s after they are kicked out of the village that Sandor suggests taking her to the Blackfish at Riverrun.  Arya says the Blackfish doesn’t know her and wouldn’t pay any ransom.  All this time he believes Sansa is still in KL.

It won’t be until Arya XIII that they learn from the Mountain’s men at the inn at the crossroads about Sansa marrying Tyrion and the Purple Wedding, as well as Riverrun being under siege.  He’s floored by this information and is resigned to the fact that he’ll never see her again.  He’s even completely out of options on where to take Arya. At least he can tell himself that she got away from the Lannisters.  

“The little bird flew away, did she? Well, bloody good for her. She shit on the Imp’s head and flew off.”   

There won’t be time to speculate on where she went, because the fight ensues and Sandor takes a “mortal” wound.          

SORRY GUYS, disregard this shitty answer.  I misread the question BADLY.  For the real answer, go to this post.

summary: Is it fair to say Sansa and Catelyn were the outsiders in the Stark family? Ned, Jon, Robb, Arya and Bran all seemed to have an...
question: Is it fair to say Sansa and Catelyn were the outsiders in the Stark family? Ned, Jon, Robb, Arya and Bran all seemed to have an idyllic dynamic with these two bringing all the conflict (Catelyn made Jon’s life living hell and Sansa bullied Arya). Rickon doesn’t seem to really factor in.
answer:
No, I do not think this is a fair or accurate representation of Stark family dynamics. Due to the accepted norms and power dynamics of their society, it’s Jon and Arya who were the (relative) outsiders, not Catelyn or Sansa. Jon is a bastard, Arya does not fit her assigned gender norms. By contrast, Catelyn is the respected Lady of Winterfell, secure in her relationships with her husband, her children, and the castle staff, while Sansa is exactly what a young noble girl is expected to be. They’re the insiders.

It’s also clear from both sisters that despite their AGoT conflict and a certain amount of tension, Sansa and Arya love each other. Arya’s and Jon’s outsider status did not preclude them having positive, loving relationships with other members of their family, as well as with each other.

By contrast, Catelyn is the respected Lady of Winterfell, secure in her relationships with her husband, her children, and the castle staff, while Sansa is exactly what a young noble girl is expected to be. They’re the insiders.

It’s also clear from both sisters that despite their AGoT conflict and a certain amount of tension, Sansa and Arya love each other. Arya’s and Jon’s outsider status did not preclude them having positive, loving relationships with other members of their family, as well as with each other.

trail.content_raw:
No, I do not think this is a fair or accurate representation of Stark family dynamics. Due to the accepted norms and power dynamics of their society, it’s Jon and Arya who were the (relative) outsiders, not Catelyn or Sansa. Jon is a bastard, Arya does not fit her assigned gender norms. By contrast, Catelyn is the respected Lady of Winterfell, secure in her relationships with her husband, her children, and the castle staff, while Sansa is exactly what a young noble girl is expected to be. They’re the insiders.

It’s also clear from both sisters that despite their AGoT conflict and a certain amount of tension, Sansa and Arya love each other. Arya’s and Jon’s outsider status did not preclude them having positive, loving relationships with other members of their family, as well as with each other.
trail.content:
No, I do not think this is a fair or accurate representation of Stark family dynamics. Due to the accepted norms and power dynamics of their society, it’s Jon and Arya who were the (relative) outsiders, not Catelyn or Sansa. Jon is a bastard, Arya does not fit her assigned gender norms. By contrast, Catelyn is the respected Lady of Winterfell, secure in her relationships with her husband, her children, and the castle staff, while Sansa is exactly what a young noble girl is expected to be. They’re the insiders.

It’s also clear from both sisters that despite their AGoT conflict and a certain amount of tension, Sansa and Arya love each other. Arya’s and Jon’s outsider status did not preclude them having positive, loving relationships with other members of their family, as well as with each other.

summary: I love the little ways the Stark girls develop together, even when apart. Sansa and Arya’s arcs first begin with the girls...
body:
I love the little ways the Stark girls develop together, even when apart.

Sansa and Arya’s arcs first begin with the girls sharpening their strongest skills: Sansa starts off as a strong writer and sewer while Arya excels in maths and physical activities. 

But by the second half of the series, they begin to learn the other’s skill-sets.  Sansa becomes more physically active and takes care of economics in the Vale while Arya turns to the arts through her time with the Braavosi theater crew.

When they reunite, they may realize they aren’t so different after all…

summary: This is random but I’m re-watching s7 and I was wondering, what is the point of Arya dining with the Lannister army? It just...
question: This is random but I’m re-watching s7 and I was wondering, what is the point of Arya dining with the Lannister army? It just seems like a useless filler scene... :/
answer:
Hey anon,

There're a couple of things I could think of to explain the scene. First, that the show wanted to humanize the Lannister soldiers both for the Starks, who have been the victims of Lannister scheming and later on for when Daenerys faces them in battle. 

I do wonder if they wanted to show the cost of war and humanize “the other side”, why didn’t they humanize the Tyrell army that got butchered by the Lannisters? If you’re going to go that route you might as well go all the way.

Secondly, perhaps it was for Arya to see that just because you serve a certain House doesn’t make you like the Lords and Lady’s of that House. She had just finishing butchering the Freys and there were probably a few Freys here and there that weren’t responsible for the Red Wedding, yet they probably paid for it. 

It could be that the scene wasn’t meant to be entirely relevant for the purpose of season 7, it might just be that there are things that might happen in season 8 that will call back to that scene. The show is known for doing that, calling back to scenes from previous seasons.  

TTFN
